rows: sin filo, mocho, desafilado, embotado, romo
ho'e ri'ka (to grill/ asar); dyo'a ri'ka
ho'e ri'ka (to grill/ asar); ʎo'a ri'ka
õ'te ri'ka (trans); õ'si bi'I ri'ka (intrans, reflex)
õ'te ri'ka (trans); õ'si bi'I ri'ka (intrans, reflex)
abalorio, mostacilla, cuenta, gota, puca; necklace=collar
Used to be used by Tukanoan peoples (and others?), sound carried for long distances

In RN region, there is typically one person per village (if that) who is a full-fledged 'shaman'. He is very much a specialist and has considerable power to cure, as well as power to curse. He is respected and feared. Shamans are thought to turn themselv

Refers to a lower-level healer; in RN region, most older men in a village have this capacity, and command a repertoire of healing spells. Power is primarily for good, whereas the true shaman is capable of malignant acts as well.
malignant forest spirit, covered with long hair, feet turned backward; in Upper Rio Negro region
espíritu malo, espíritu maligno, fantasma, demonio
In RN region, frequently translates as 'Bone-Son', 'One on the bone', etc.
carrizo, zampoñas, flautas de pan, rondadora
only gathered in wild throughout Amazonia?
yurupari, jurupari (or any flutes forbidden to women)
a ritual complex in various parts of Amazonia involving sacred flutes/trumpets, forbidden to women.
fetiche, encanto, filtro de amor,  pusanga
currently limited to certain groups (favoring h-g orientation, e.g. Nadahup) within RN region
esp. for fanning a cooking fire
Interesting correlation to 'fish' in Tukanoan languages
esp. for grating manioc, but can be used for other things as well
grid of sticks for smoking meat or placing objects (shelf)
pilón, mano de mortero, mazo, moledor
prioritizes manioc beer where distinction is made
usually manioc; agriculture, but also can be made from certain wild seeds/fruits
tipiti, matafrio, sebucán, exprimador, prensa para yuca
word of Tupi origin; agriculture: specifically for squeezing poison out of manioc
hunting, currently is falling out of use in Vaupés region, associated primarily with h-g groups (but this may be recent?)
agriculture? commonly used for sifting dry manioc flour
can refer to worms; more generic
if different word from top grinding stone
use word for top grinding stone if different from bottom stone
mitu, montete (Peru), paujil/panjuil (Peru), paujil de Salvin (Peru for Mitu salvini)
Northern Amazonia (N of Solimões), not in northern Colombia; Dark-winged trumpeter is found south of Solimões
Different types have different localized ranges
doubtful loan into protolg - WW? onomatopoeic?
loro real, loro (Sp. form is a loan from Carib)
sachaperro, Perro de Monte, Zorro Vinagre, Guanfando; Zorro Ojizarco, Zorro Negro, Perro de Orejas Corta
oso hormiguero; tapia pelejo or pelejo chico for Cyclopes didactylus

Melanosuchus niger, Caiman schlerops; Paleosuchus sp.
Port term reportedly borrowed from Tupi
maparate (used in Peru for some types of catfish, including Auchenipterus sp.), cunchi (used in Peru for some types of catfish), bagre (catfish)
iguana' is reportedly from Arawak iwana
boa; mantona (red-tailed boa); boa de altura

prioritize generic term that includes any edible species
Mature forests of Rio Negro and Upper Amazon
may be confused in some entries with O. bataua
moriche (Col, Ven), aguaje (Col, Peru), achual, miriti
Brazil, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Peru, Venezuela; in and near swamps
pui, irapay, hoja de irapay, caraná
Mauritiella armata OR Lepidocaryum tenue (irapay), Mauritius carana
Mauritia carana is limited principally to the Rio Negro and Upper Orinoco regions; dry catinga forests
chontaduro (Col, Ecuador); pipire (Col); pijuayo (Peru), pijiguao (Ven); tembe (Bol)
ungurahui (Peru), palma de seje, milpesos, patabá
mostly north of Equator; common in Amazonia
may be confused with O. bacaba - compare entries
secondary scrub vegetation. lower alt. of eastern Andes
Gossypium (barbadense: long fibers; hirsutum: short fibers)
plant; some sources may confound with kapok Ceiba pentandra (esp. if a single gloss for 'cotton' is given')
ceiba, huimba, lupuna (Peru for Ceiba sp.)
northern South America and central America; common in disturbed areas
Capsicum sp., principally chinensis and frutescens
maní (may be loan from Taino Arawak), cacahuete
caña flecha, caña brava, caña isana
banano, banana, cambur, bellaco, variedad de plátano
Names for banana/plantain may be derived from bastard plantain by semantic shift.
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
Secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens. North and South America (Brazil, Peru, Bolivia, Suriname, Colombia)
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
tortuga caspi, pretina (Peru for tree and tumpline); carahuasca (Peru)
Duguetia sp. OR Fusaea longifolia OR Guatteria chrysopetala
castanha do para (B. excelsa); castanha de cutia (C. edulis)
Bertholletia excelsa [cf. Couepia edulis 'castanha do cutia']

1) Couepia: restricted area within Brazil, Rio Purus basin and middle Solimões.  2) Bertholletia: elev: consistently about 200m; mature forests. Widely distributed from Peru, E. Colombia, Brazil to Nicaragua.
anarcado, castaña de cajú, nuez de la India, marañon, cajú, merey (Venezuela)
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
tree; most sources will not distinguish between occidentale and other varieties
jagua, majagua - Colombia, caruto, xagua - Venezuela, bigrande - Bolivia, huito, yaguayagua - Peru, ygualti - Nicaragua, maluco - Mexico
native to NW Amazonia, found primarily in Vaupes and Caqueta regions
other species of Pouteria exist and have much-used edible fruit; these can be subsituted where relevant
uva de monte, uvilla (Peru), puruma, caime, caimarona (and variants; Col.)
grows wild in Western Amazon basin; cultivated in Colombia since pre-Colombian times
a tree; not a true grape

not generally cultivated in western (subAndean) Amazon. Arroyo-Kalin (2010) argues for a correlation with distribution of dark earths, mostly formed after 1AD, and the modeled-incised pottery tradition.

Provides more starch and is more pest-resistant than the sweet variety, but requires much processing. Arroyo-Kalin (2010) proposes that bitter type was developed from sweet through post-ceremic agricultural intensification (motivated by high starch yield
Primary staple in western/subAndean Amazonia, less important elsewhere
No processing required, but lower starch yield and pest resistance than bitter variety

calabazo, calabaza; auyama (Dominican Republic and Venezuela), ayote (parts of Central America), zapallo (parts of South America), tutumo/totumo/totuma (Cresc tree), huingo (Peru for Crescentia cujete), tapara
Crescentia cujete (round variety - tree); (Cucurbita) Lagenaria siceraria (bottle variety - vine)
secondary forests and secondary srcrub  vegetation
semi-domesticated, native to Amazonian basin, esp. NW
bullet ant, lesser giant hunter ant

Colombia: zampopo, hormiga arriera; Venezuela: bachaco; Peru: curuhuinse
Apis mellifera; Tetragonisca angustula; Trigona amazonensis
lampírido, luciérnaga (Peru), añañahui (Peru), cocuyo   (attributed Taino origin)
doubtful loan into protolanguage, direction unknown
Mono Lanudo Común, Choro, Churucu, mono choro (Peru), mono lanudo cafe, barrigudo de Humboldt
Arawak, cf. Piapoco ìisi; s > h regular in Tanimuca
mono negro (Peru), Machín Negro, Maicero Cachón, mono maicero
Machín Blanco, mono blanco, Maicero Cariblanco, mono blanco (Peru)
Machin Blanco, Mono Araña de Vientre Amarillo, maquisapa (Peru), braceadora (Colombia)

Nutria, Lobo de Agua, lobito de rio, perro de agua (Colombia)
sajino, pecarí de collar, jabalf, Javelina, Saíno, Pecarí de Collar
Guatusa Negra, Añuje, Agutí (black-rumped), picure, jochi colorado
Guatín, Punchana, curi, picurito rabudo, picurito rabilargo
Cuniculus paca (Agouti paca is sometimes used as well although cuniculus is the correct term.)
Analysis posits that the stop is the most relevant underlying phoneme. Comment in notes on whether the nasal contour is understood as a phonetic (allophonic) effect, or is phonologically contrastive.
Neither consonant clusters nor closed syllables are permitted except that a glottal stop may occur following any vowel.
Does the language have long and short vowels?
I checked Gaviria and found NO evidence (although it is not as clear a source; p.75-85 in Gav.)
Onset consists of more than one consonant phoneme
Neither consonant clusters nor closed syllables are permitted except that a glottal stop may follow a vowel
The Retuarã syllable conforms to the pattern: (C)V(V)(V).
Do all syllables end in a consonant?
Stressed syllables often occur with raised pitch.(high/low level)
Does stress occur on different syllables with meaning difference?
Nasalization property of morpheme or syllable
In contrast to nasalization as a property of segments
Nasal spreading across some morpheme boundaries
Do some affixes or other morphemes take the nasal/oral properties of the root they attach to?
Nasalization spreads both progressively and regressively. Nasal spreading is blocked by obstruents (except /dy/)
Verbal fusion (2+ categories marked by portmanteau morphemes on verb)
Verb combines two or more categories (tense, aspect, mood, person, number, etc.) in portmanteau morphemes{ [ignore proclitics unless they are fused with values other than person/number]
Inflection manifested by replacement of segmental or suprasegmental phonemes
There are very few morphophonemic changes in the language. The person prefixes display most of these changes.
Verbal synthesis (1+ inflectional categories marked by verbal affixes)
Morphological complexity in verbs - multiple inflectional affixes in a single verb word
There are many more prefixes than suffixes
The only prefixes in the language are cliticized subject pronouns and one nonhuman object pronoun.
There are many more suffixes than prefixes
Affixation is done overwhelmingly by suffix.
The person marker prefixes are the only prefixes of the language.
Prefixing/suffixing inflectional morph: roughly equal or one weakly preferred
The numbers of suffixes and prefixes are not notably different
Only part of the morpheme is reduplicated
Noun compounds created from two noun phrases are common and systematically produced
Verb roots can be combined in a single predicate without markers of subordination (distinct from subordinating construction) or distinct inflection
Serial verb constructions involve chaining of roots together in one morphophonological word
There is a set of semantically weak verbs used in complex verbal constructions, e.g. 'take a nap'

In addition to the main verb, subject markers (prefix and suffix), object marker (prefix), negative and causative affixes, the verb phrase also includes the adjuncts; Auxiliary verb, tense, aspect, mood, intensifiers, evidentials, and subordinating suffix
epps-may be obligatory (like do in english whereas 27 would be more like can, should, may, etc.
There are verbs that accompany main verbs of clauses and take grammatical marking not expressed by main verbs
The auxiliary verb baa 'do, make' is used to create a construction that indicates imminence.
The auxiliary takes the tense suffic while the content verb takes the subject prefix.
Incorporation of nouns into verbs is a productive intransitivizing process
Sometimes objects and instruments are incorporated into the verb.  The incorporated constituent directly precedes the verb root.
The incorporation of the object may can reduce the valence of the verb to make it grammatically instransitive.
Productive incorporation of other elements (adjectives, locatives, etc.) into verbs
Like noun incorporation, but incorporated  elements are not nouns
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Nouns are organized into sets with distinct morphological treatment; usually affects all nouns and involves agreement within the NP
Relative clauses, dependent clauses, and nearly every noun is marked as a nominal with a number/gender suffix.
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Note the (approximate) total number of noun classes/genders
Nouns are categorized according to animacy, number, and gender.
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Nouns are organized into sets, but only a limited set of nouns may be implicated, with no or limited agreement marking. If only numeral classifiers exist, indicate yes but explain.
Whereas noun class and predicate adjective categorization have relevance outside the NP, classifiers categorize nouns within the NP according to gender, number, animacy, and shape function.
The six classes include: masculine and animate singular, feminine singular, masculine and animate dual, masculine and animate plural, feminine plural, and inanimate.
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Sex is a relevant category in noun class(ification) system for animates
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Sex is a relevant category in noun class(ification) system for inanimates
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Animacy (w/o reference to sex) is a relevant category in the noun class(ification) system
1. Neuter (nonhuman or inanimate) 2. Human masculine singular 3. Human feminine singular 4. Human plural
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Sex/gender distinction only in 3rd person pronouns
add in notes section whether gender is present in other PNs or not in any PNs; consider with reference to pronouns and person marking only
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Shape is a relevant category in the noun class(ification) system for animates
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Shape is a relevant category in the noun class(ification) system for inanimates
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Where no distinct classifier exists, a copy of the noun itself may function in the morphosyntactic classifier "slot"
In some cases, the head of the noun phrase appears to be copied onto the modifier to create the classifier (but drops the nominalizer.)
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Special classifier forms that occur only with numerals
Classifiers occur obligatory bound to numerals and optionally to adjectives and demonstratives.
Nominal Categories - Gender and noun classification
Classifiers used as derivational suffixes to derive nouns
Verb + classifier = 'thing for doing V, thing that does V, etc.'
The affix -ri occurs after a verb root and has the function of deverbalization
Singular number may be marked on the noun
Often occurs in a small subset of nouns if a single entity is referred to, e.g. insects that normally occur in groups
Plural marked by stem change or tone on noun
Plural marked by reduplication of noun
Plural marked on human or animate nouns only
There are 3 animate plural markers for numbers; -rã '2', -bãki '2+masc.', -korã 'fem'
Attached to the classifier which procedes the head of the NP.
Pronominal plural: stem + nominal plural affix
Pronouns use a nominal plural affix not specific to pronouns
e.g. 'John and his associates', 'John and them'
Definite = particular referent known to both speaker and addressee; specific = particular referent known to speaker only
There are demonstratives but no definite or indefinite articles.
Marker of definiteness distinct from demonstratives
Focus on articles/markers whose primary function is to mark definiteness
Retuarã has no definite or indefinite article.
Inclusive  =us + you, exclusive = us but not you
This free form of the pronoun generally occurs as an abbreviated answer to a question, or when it is the subject of certain types of clauses.(yiha-1p pl excl. bãrã-1p pl inclusive)
The personal pronouns are not frequently used, perhaps because the person marker prefixes are preferred.
The forms occur prefixed to the verb root that begins with a consonant. Before a vowel, the last vowel of the prefix may be deleted or assimilated.
The rules differ somewhat for each morpheme.
Note the number of distances in the demonstrative system
Other contrasts in demonstratives (visibility, elevation, etc.)
Polite pronominal variants or differential avoidance of pronouns
e.g. English 'himself', Spanish 'se'; distinct form(s) from basic (non-reflexive) pronominals; distinct from reflexive verbal affix
The only overt method to express a reflexive is to use poʔia 'body' as the object.
Overtyly marked reflexives are rare in Retuarã. Instead, when the subject receives he action of a verb that could be transitive, the absence of an object noun phrase makes the reflexive implicit.
Prepositions or postpositions mark subjects, objects, beneficiaries/recipients
The case markers are postposition clitics on the last word in the noun phrase.
Case markers indicate the relationship of a noun phrase to the verb of a clause (also marks the relationship between two noun phrases in the same clause in the case of accompaniment.)
Note the number of grammatical relations that may be morphologically marked on the noun
Retuarã uses postpositions to mark case using the eight markers; -re/-te 'Term', -rã 'Loc', -reka 'Loc.Spec', -ka-gener/number 'Abl', -pe 'Instr', -ka 'Com', -rʔsi 'Ben', -ri-gender/number 'Poss'
Case: only non-core arguments morphologically marked
Subjects, objects, beneficiaries/recipients NOT marked, but other grammatical relations are
All NPs marked if in appropriate syntactic relation; no distinction in marking based on semantics (type of entity)
Semantically defined subset of NPs marked for case, e.g. animates
The suffix -re marks subjects or objects which are human or referred to by a proper name.
The case markers are postposition clitics on the last word in the noun phrase.
Same marking for 'with a person' and 'with an instrument'
The case marker -pi indicates instrument and -ka is used to indicate both coparticipant and conjunction.
At least some part of the system involves base-2
At least some part of the system involves base-5
The number system is base five until the number twenty.
At least some part of the system involves base-10
The Retuarã numbers one through ten are still widely used.
After twenty, counting is by increments of twenty.
Etymological transparency in any numerals under 5
'Many' or some other non-exact term used
The Retuarã numbers one through ten are still widely used.
'Many' or some other non-exact term used
The number constructions are long and cumbersome, even for native speakers so that young men may consult older men about accurate pronunciation of numbers between eleven and twenty.
Tense or aspect inflection on non-verbal predicates
Pronominal possessive affixes: prefix on N
Pronominal possessive affixes: suffix on N
The case marker -rika 'possessive' comes from the verb rika 'to have' and marks a normally human noun phrase as a possessor or owner.
Head/dependent marking in possessive NP: dependent
Head/dependent marking in possessive NP: head
There are special classifiers that occur with possessed entities
The case marker -rika 'possessive' comes from the verb rika 'to have' and marks a normally human noun phrase as a possessor or owner.
The possessive case marker agrees in gender and number with the possessed object.
Where inalienable possession differs from alienable, the former takes a morphological marker (may include an associated free particle/pronoun)
Where inalienable possession differs from alienable, the latter takes a morphological marker (may include an associated free particle/pronoun)
Default marker for inalienably possessed nouns if unpossessed
An inalienable noun that is in an unpossessed state must have a derivational affix or associated form
Generic human nouns are obligatorily bound/possessed
Human nouns must co-occur with another noun (e.g. Hup-man, NonIndian-woman, but *man)
There are underived adjectives which do not have counterparts in other word classes
Gender inflection on adjectives within the NP
There is gender agreement/concord (animate/inanimate or masc/fem, etc.) within the NP, e.g. la casa blanca, el perro blanco
The great majority of both adjectives and nouns end with the neuter noun class suffixes -a or -ka
There is a morpheme which derives an event from a verb
Participles marked with -eʔka involve tense and imply an event.(p.87)
There is a morpheme which derives an agent or subject from a verb
There is a morpheme which derives a patient or object from a verb
Retuarã allows a variety of object complements, that is, clauses embedded as the object of the verb.
There is a morpheme which derives a verb from a noun or adjective
NP coordination and comitative phrases marked differently
'John and Mary went to market' is marked differently from 'John went to market with Mary'
The case-marker -ka 'comitative', indicates both coparticipant and conjunction.
Past tense is regularly morphologically marked on the verb or elsewhere
Multiple past tenses, distinguishing distance from time of reference
Multiple future tenses, distinguishing distance from time of reference
Unlike the past tenses, there are no distinctions that depend on the proximity of the projected event to the moment of speaking.
Future tense is indicated by the suffix -rãyu.
Future tense is indicated by the suffix -rãyu.
The future tense has a nominalized form that is used for future descriptions or conditions; the form is composed of -rã (future) plus a number/gender suffix.
Dedicated imperative morpheme or verb form
There is a special morpheme (or morphemes, or a bare verb root where inflection is normally expected) used to signal imperative (command) mood
Retuarã has second-person imperatives, indirect & negative imperatives, horatory forms, and third-person imperatives.
There is a distinct morpheme for polite imperative constructions (specify if it has other functions in the language)
The indirect imperative is also used for courtesy; it seems to soften a command.
Difference between negation in imperative (prohibitive) and declarative clauses
There are different strategies for marking negation in imperative and declarative clauses

In declarative or interrogative sentences, the suffix -be negates the clause and follows the verb root (scopes the whole sent.) Negation of imperatives is accomplished by suffixing -aʔsi to the verb root, and constituents are negated by the neg. verb bã
Dedicated hortative morpheme or verb form (1pl or 3rd person imperative)
as opposed to imperative; the person in control of desired state of affairs is not the addressee; ex: 'Let's sing' / 'Let him sing'
Inflectional marking of capacity to do something
Marking of expected/unexpected action or result
There is inflectional marking of expected/unexpected
The modal -kope(contra-expectation) indicates a situation where the expected result of some proposition is frustrated and does not occur.
The habitual aspect suffix -wai does not indicate an event as occurring at a specific time but rather as charactericitc of all time.
There is a single morpheme or verb form to mean '(be careful lest) X happens'
The negative imperative can also be used with first- and third-person subjects, in which case it means 'lest'.
There are dedicated morpheme(s) for realis/irrealis 'actualized/unactualized events'
There are four modal suffixes which indicate non-actual (irrealis) events.
Note whether these inflectional markers are positive or negative
Directional elements affixed to the verb
There are grammaticalized elements indicating movement away, toward, there and back, etc.
There are three directionals that suffix directly to the verb root.
Indicates information has been witnessed visually - indicate only if an overt marker
Unlike many Tucanoan languages, the evidential system in Retuarã is small and not frequently used.
Indicates information has been sensed firsthand but not visually (usually heard; also smelled, tasted, felt)
The affix -ko(auditory) follows the verb stem and indicates that the source of information for the statement is auditory.
Indicates information has not been experienced firsthand, but inferred from some kind of evidence - indicate only if an overt marker.
The evidential affix -rihi (assumed) indicates that the basis for the speaker's statement is assumption.
Indicates speaker is not responsible for veracity of statement, merely reporting; 'allegedly'
This evidential indicates that the source of the information is not first hand; he or she is just passing on what was reported to him or her.
Indicate presence of adjacent representation of repeated discourse
Any other evidential values not represented above
Whereas in other Tucanoan languages, evidentials are a mandatory feature of the independent verb, in Retuarã the evidentials are optional.
Word order is rigid only for the subject, which, apart from negative decalaritives, occurs before other major constituents.
The basic constituents of an intransitive sentence are an intransitive verb preceded by a free subject or a subject prefix.
The basic order of a transitive clause is SOV.
In a transitive clause, the object often precedes the verb.

A subject noun phrase precedes the object so that in potentially ambiguous sentences where the subject and object cannot be distinguished by case marking nor semantic clues, they are distinguished by word order.
Noun phrases may be case-marked by postposition suffixes attached to the last word in the phrase.
Possessive phrase composed of a free possessor and its possessum has possessor first (e.g. John's book)
Possessive phrase composed of a free possessor and its possessum has possessum first (e.g. 'book of John')
The adjective generally precedes the head in Retuarã.
Adjectives may follow the noun, however, and such phrases in isolation may be interpreted as a noun phrase or as a descriptive clause with a predicate adj and an implicit copula.
As modifiers they precede the head in a noun phrase but like adjectives, they follow the head noun when used as a predicate.
Numerals preced the head and have an obligatory classifier follwing the numeral.
Relative clause follows noun that it modifies
Relative clause precedes noun that it modifies
e.g. 'the dog cat chased-NMZR got away' ('the cat that the dog chased got away')
Clauses may be subordinated as internally headed relative clauses, object complements, or adverbial clauses.
Relative clause is correlative or adjoined
e.g. 'what is running, the dog chased that cat'
'what', 'who', etc. come first in interrogative clause
Alignment of case marking in full NPs: nominative-accusative w/ marked accusative
Objects of transitive clauses ('P') have a unique marker, while subjects of transitive ('A') and intransitive ('S') clauses are unmarked or share a different marker from that occurring on objects
Alignment of case marking in full NPs: nominative-accusative w/ marked nominative
Subjects of transitive and intransitive clauses share a marker, while objects of transitives are unmarked
Alignment of case marking in full NPs: ergative-absolutive
Subjects of intransitive clauses and objects of transitives share a unique marker, while subjects of transitive clauses are unmarked or have a different marker
Alignment of case marking in full NPs: tripartite
Intransitive subjects, transitive subjects, and transitive objects all receive distinct case markers
Alignment of case marking in full NPs: active-inactive

Subjects of intransitive clauses are treated two different ways: like subjects of transitives if they are more agent-like (e.g. he jumped), and like objects of transitives if they are more patient-like (e.g. he fell asleep)
Alignment of case marking of pronouns: marked accusative
When the subject and object are both pronouns (animate), the pronoun marked with -re is the object or recipient.
Alignment of case marking of pronouns: marked nominative
Subject pronouns are usually cliticized and prefixed to the verb (and thus are not case-marked.
Alignment of case marking of pronouns: ergative-absolutive
Alignment of case marking of pronouns: tripartite
Alignment of case marking of pronouns: active-inactive
Same as above, for pronominal affixes/clitics on verbs
Marking of A and P depends on their relative ranking on a hierarchy (usually 1>2>3 or 2>1>3)
More than one of the above systems is represented in person marking, depending on e.g. person (e.g. 1/2 vs. 3), tense-aspect value, main vs. subordinate clause type, etc.
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Pronominal subjects: pronouns in subject position
Pronominal subjects are free pronouns that occur in the same position as full NP subjects
Subject pronouns are usually cliticized and prefixed to the verb.
Free subject pronouns are always postverbal in negative declaritive sentences.
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Pronominal subjects are marked as verbal prefixes (free pronouns may be another option)
Subject pronouns are usually cliticized and prefixed to the verb (and thus are not case-marked.)
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Pronominal subjects are marked as verbal suffixes (free pronouns may be another option)
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Pronominal subjects: clitics on variable host
Pronominal subjects are clitics that can attach to verbs, nominal constituents, etc.
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Pronominal subjects: pronouns in non-subject position
Pronominal subjects are free pronouns but do not normally occur in the position expected for full NP subjects
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Person marking (of agents) on transitive verbs
Subject pronouns are usually cliticized and prefixed to the verb.
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
It is also common to have just the object pronoun prefixed to the verb when the subject is a full noun phrase.
It appears you can have both subj and object marked on verb (just not at the same time)
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
3rd person zero in verbal person marking: subjects
3rd person subjects are not overtly marked within the verbal person-marking system
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
3rd person zero in verbal person marking: objects
3rd person objects are not overtly marked within the verbal person-marking system
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Number can be marked separately from person on the verb
Verbal person marking exists, but number is (or can) be marked separately
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Possessive affixes/clitics on nouns are same as verbal person markers
Where nouns take possessive affixes, these are the same as the person-marking affixes
Simple Clauses - Pronouns and person marking
Gender distinguished in verbal person markers
For any person, verbal person markers exhibit different forms depending on the gender (masc/fem, animate/inanimate, etc.) of the referent
In ditransitives (e.g. 'John gives a book to Bill'), the theme (book) is treated in the same way as are objects of transitives, while the recipient/beneficiary (Bill) is treated differently
In ditransitives (e.g. 'John gives Bill a book'), both the theme (book) and the recipient/beneficiary (Bill) is treated in the same way as are objects of transitives
The roles of the object noun phrases are semantically interpreted, not grammatically marked.
In ditransitives, the recipient/beneficiary is treated in the same way as are objects of transitives, while the theme (book) is treated differently
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Decreasing
Verb becomes reciprocal through use of reciprocal morpheme associated with the verb (may be attached to the verb root). This morpheme is only used to mean reciprocal.
Reciprocality may be overtly marked by -bua (reciprcal) following the verb root.
As with reflexives, some verbs are inherently reciprocal.
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Decreasing
Verb becomes reflexive through use of reflexive morpheme associated with the verb (may be attached to the verb root). This morpheme is used only to mean reflexive.
Overtly marked reflexives are rare in Retuarã.
Instead, when the subject receives the action of a verb that could be transitive, the absence of an object noun phrase makes the reflexive implicit.
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Decreasing
Verb becomes reciprocal or reflexive through use of a morpheme that means either reciprocal or reflexive which attaches to the root of the verb
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Decreasing
Passive voice usually involves a change to the verb, while the object of the active voice verb is promoted to subject in the passive voice, and the former subject is deleted/demoted
The subject can be both agent and patient.
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Decreasing
Like passive, but deletes or demotes the object of a transitive verb; usually found in ergative languages
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Decreasing
There is/are some other mechanism(s) for reducing valency
Some intransitive verbs are the product of object incorporation which reduces the valence of transitive verbs.
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
Applicative adds a beneficiary/maleficiary object argument to the verb
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
Applicative adds some other object argument to the verb
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
Causative is morphological and is attached before the root of the verb
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
Causative is morphological and is attached after the root of the verb
The morphological causitive is formed by adding a causative suffix immediately after the verb root.
The causee is the object or recipient of the verb.
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
Causative marked by circumfix, stem change, or tone
Morphological causative other than simple prefix/suffix
There are evidences of a variety of past processes of causative formation that are no longer productive.
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
Causative: serial verb or analytical construction
Causative construction that involves periphrasis or serialization
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
Indicates that the causer does not directly cause the action of the verb to be realized, but does so by inducing someone else to carry out the action, e.g. 'John had the house painted.'
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
Indicates that causer participates in event
Simple Clauses - Valence and voice - Increasing
There is/are some other mechanism(s) for increasing valency
Clausal negator is a preposed element
Clausal negator is a preposed element
Clausal negator is a postposed element
Clausal negator is a postposed element
Sentence negation is expressed by the verbal suffix -be which immegiately follows the verb root
Standard (non-emphatic) negation typically requires two morphemes, e.g. French 'ne V pas'
Distinct negative form for 'NP does not exist'
Lexical expression or highly idiomatic phrase
Yes/no questions distinguished from declaratives by interrogative particle
Questions are formed by adding a question marker to an indicative clause. The question marker is usually clause initial.
Yahe does not occur in negative questions. Bai extends only to constituents of the sentence and can occur in positive or negative
Yes/no questions distinguished from declaratives by interrogative verb morphology
Yes/no questions distinguished from declaratives by word order (esp. subject-verb inversion)
Yes/no questions distinguished from declaratives by intonation only
Typically the intonation of a question rises slightly at the end.
Content questions: word order differs from declaratives
Content questions distinguished from declaratives by word order (esp. subject-verb inversion) as well as by presence of Q-word (who, what, etc.)
Adjectives act like verbs in predicative position
Adjectives act like nouns in predicative position
In isolation may be interpreted as a noun phrase or as a descriptive clause with a predicate adjective and an implicit copula.
Zero copula for predicate nominals is possible
Predicate nominals may occur without a copula (i.e. grammatical in some circumstances, if not all)
Predicate nominals can also be formed using a deictic pronoun or a personal pronoun when the copula is omitted.
The copula in Retuarã is the verb ibã.
Compare Eng 'the one that fell' (but in Eng 'one' could be considered a head)

When relativizing into the subject, object, or recipient and the head of the relative clause is pronominal, rather than full NP, the pronoun is omitted and the head is referred to only by the number/gender suffix
Relative clauses in Retuarã are not common.
Headless relative clauses are the dominant or only form of relative clause
Relative clauses that form a constituent with a head noun (in a single noun phrase) are rare or nonexistent; some descriptions may refer to adjoined or correlative clauses.
Relative clause may occur with a noun classifier/class marker
It may be unclear whether the classifier is the nominal head of the construction or is an agreement marker on the relative clause
Morphological relativizer is homophonous with nominalizer
The same morpheme marks a relative clause and is a nominalizer on verbs (and/or other word classes)
Indicates that the subject desires to carry out the action denoted by the verb (distinct from verb 'want', but may be grammaticalized from it)
Clauses can be grouped such that only one bears most of the verb morphology, and the others are marked as to whether they share a subject with this reference clause.
There are special markers to indicate same vs. different subject when two clauses are combined
Morphologically marked distinction between simultaneous and sequential clauses
Morphology (usually on verb) distinguishes between clauses denoting events that occur at the same time or in sequence

The suffix -baraka indicates that the event of the subordinate clause is simultaneous with the event of the matrix clause. The suffix -tirã indicates that the event of the subordinate clause immediately precedes the event of the matrix clause.

name: Tanimuca
Data Sources:
Gaviria, Sofia Victoria and Luis José Azcárate. 1979. Fonología y lexicología de la lengua tanimuka. Bogotá: Universidad de los Andes, Facultad de Artes y Ciencias, Departamento de Antropología. 

Huber, R.; Reed, R. 1992. Comparative vocabulary: selected words in indigenous languages of Colombia. Instituto Linguistico de Verano.

Mountain, Kathy. 1978. Lista de Palabras Swadesh y Rowe. Linguística y Campos Apines. Anderson, Martha y Bonnie Brobston, eds.

Rodriguez, José Vicente, compiler, and others.  1995.  Mamíferos colombianos: sus nombres comunes e indígenas.  Bogotá: Conservation International, Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.

Strom, Clay. 1992. Retuarã Syntax. (Summer Institute of Linguistics: Publications in Linguistics, 112.) The Summer Institute of Linguistics and the University of Texas at Arlington. (Studies in the Indigenous Languages of Colombia 3).
Features:
Basic Vocabulary
Flora Fauna Vocabulary
Cultural Vocabulary
Grammatical Data
Ethnographic Information
